Graphical abstract This work presented a comprehensive study on structure sensitivity of phase-pure M1 catalyst in oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane (ODHE). We proposed an effective method to modulate the morphology of phase-pure M1 catalysts by oxalic acid treatment. The proposed approach significantly promoted the catalyst surface area by restraining the anisotropic growth of the basal (001) plane of the M1-phase in calcination and decreased the diameter of M1 needles. Experimental results showed that phase-pure M1 catalyst treated with 1.0mmol/L oxalic acid solution exhibited remarkably promoted catalyst performance of 73% ethane conversion, 85% ethylene selectivity and 0.77k C2H4/kgcat/h catalyst productivity at 400°C. The serial catalyst tests also demonstrated the structure sensitivity of M1 phase in the ODHE reaction. Active sites were located on the lateral faces as well as the basal plane of the M1 needles, but different effects on the catalyst selectivity were observed. The phase-pure M1 catalyst with a lower aspect ratio was suggested to provide better ethylene selectivity in ODHE process. Keywords Oxidative dehydrogenation Ethane Ethylene Mixed metal oxide Oxalic acid treatment 1 Introduction The oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane (ODHE) has been extensively considered as an attractive route for ethylene production compared with traditional steam cracking and catalytic dehydrogenation over the past few decades [1–11]. The metal oxides and metal mixed oxides have been investigated as the promising ODHE catalysts since 1970s due to their great benefits of high theoretical ethane conversion, low energy consumption and low risk of catalyst deactivation caused by carbon deposition [1–6]. Various metal oxide catalysts show high activity for CH bond breaking in the ODHE reaction, including several unreducible metal oxides (i.e. Li, Na, Mg) [7–9] at temperature higher than 600°C and some reducible metal oxides (i.e. Ni, Mo, V) [10–34] at temperature lower than 500°C. Among all the catalytic systems, a multicomponent catalyst based on MoVNbTe mixed oxides is one of the most outstanding catalysts for ODHE [21–34], which has great potential to achieve the economic feasibility of the process at 60–80% ethane conversion, more than 90% ethylene selectivity and 1.00kgC2H4/kgcat/h catalyst productivity below 500°C [35–39]. Unfortunately, the existing research in the literature has not reached the goal so far for lacking the effective way to promote the catalyst performance. The MoVNbTeOx catalyst usually consists of M1 and M2 crystalline phases as well as minor amounts of other phases such as Mo5O14-type structures, MoV and MoTe oxides [21–24]. M1 is an orthorhombic phase with space group Pba2, while M2 is a pseudo-hexagonal phase with space group P6mm [40,41]. Previous studies have indicated that M1 phase possesses only V5+ ions as the ethane activation sites [42–45] and the performance of MoVNbTeOx catalysts increases with the purity of M1 phase [25]. Phase-pure M1 catalyst can be prepared by hydrothermal synthesis or slurry method with suitable purification process [28,46–49]. M1 phase is built by center occupied pentagonal rings that are connected by corner sharing MO6 octahedrons (M=Mo,V), which are assembled in the (001) plane to form characteristic hexagonal and heptagonal rings hosting TeO units [50]. A bronze-like channel structure grows along the (001) direction. As a result, needlelike crystal morphology finally forms, in which the (001) planes are perpendicular to the length axis of the needle. Usually the phase-pure M1 catalyst is in the size of 50–100nm in width and about 200nm in length [48,49]. The function of terminating (001) planes of the M1 phase in the catalytic conversion of alkanes has been extensively discussed, where various methods have been used to prepare model catalyst with different exposed ratio of (001) planes for detailed investigation [50–57]. Celaya Sanfiz et al., prepared the M1 model catalyst exclusively exposing (001) planes by complete silylation of M1 followed by breakage of the SiO2-covered M1 needles [55]. Kolen’ko et al., prepared three M1 model catalysts with different particle size by different synthesis method and chemical sources [56]. Their results indicated that there was no obvious structure sensitivity of phase-pure M1 catalyst in the selective oxidation of propane. However, the silylation of M1 catalyst may change its surface adsorption property, while the M1 catalyst prepared from different synthesis method and chemical sources cannot promise the same surface chemistry property (i.e. metal valence). A tunable particle size synthesis method of phase-pure M1 catalyst is necessary to obtain more credible results in the investigation of structure sensitivity of M1 phase in ODHE reaction. Our previous work has shown that the morphology of M1 phase particles is sensitive to the treatment condition during the catalyst preparation which may affect the catalyst activity and selectivity [58]. In the present work, we focus on the post-treatment with oxalic acid and the particle size of phase-pure M1 catalyst can be modified with almost no effect on the other chemical or physical properties. The mechanism of oxalic acid treatment and structure sensitivity of M1 phase in ODHE reaction are also investigated and discussed in details. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation MoVNbTeOx catalysts were prepared by hydrothermal synthesis in a 100-mL Teflon autoclave following the oxalic acid treatment and H2O2 purification in sequence. The general preparation procedure is illustrated in details in Scheme 1 . Phase-pure M1 catalysts with different particle size were obtained by oxalic acid treatment with different concentration, named as M1-N (N is the concentration of oxalic acid at the unit of mmol/L). The general preparation procedure is described in details as below. (i) Hydrothermal synthesis Ammonium heptamolybdate (Sigma-Aldrich, 99.0%), vanadyl sulfate (Sigma-Aldrich, 97%), telluric acid (Sigma-Aldrich, 98%) and ammonium niobium oxalate (Sigma-Aldrich, 99.99%) were used as the starting materials to prepare the initial slurry precursor containing the metals in a molar ratio of Mo/V/Te/Nb=1/0.25/0.23/0.12. Ammonium heptamolybdate of 4.46g, vanadyl sulfate of 1.63g and telluric acid of 1.35g were dissolved in 50mL deionized water as the solution 1, while ammonium niobium oxalate of 1.18g was dissolved in 25mL deionized water as the solution 2 at 80°C. Solution 1 was stirred at 80°C for 30min and turned to yellow slurry. Solution 2 was added to solution 1 after cooled down to 40°C and stirred for 10min. After replacement of residual air in the slurry precursor by nitrogen, hydrothermal synthesis was carried out at 175°C for 48h. • Oxalic acid treatment The obtained suspensions after hydrothermal synthesis were filtrated and the precipitate was washed with 200mL deionized water. The solid precursor material was then added into the solution of oxalic acid (Sigma-Aldrich, 99.0%) with the concentration of 0–60mmol/L and stirred at 60°C for 2h. It was filtrated, dried at 80°C overnight in air and calcinated at 600°C for 2h in nitrogen. • H2O2 purification 10% H2O2 solution was used to purify the MoVNbTe oxide mixture of M1 and M2 phases till the M2 phase was totally dissolved during the stirring at 60°C for 2h. Phase-pure M1 catalysts with different particle size were obtained after filtration, washing and drying at 110°C overnight. 2.2 Catalyst testing M1 catalyst of 0.5g was loaded in a small fixed-bed reactor (i.e., a quartz tube with 8mm i.d. and 750mm in length) for catalyst testing of ODHE process. The catalyst was diluted with 5.0g SiC particles (Sigma-Aldrich, 99.0%, 0.1–0.2mm in diameter) to minimize the heat effects during the reaction. A movable thermal couple of 1.0mm diameter was inserted from the reactor outlet to the packed catalyst bed in order to measure the temperature profile. The gas feed consisted of ethane, oxygen and helium at a total flow rate of 30mL/min and a C2H6/O2/He molar ratio of 30/20/50. The reaction temperature was maintained at 400°C. The contact time defined as W/FC2H6 (W is the mass of M1 phase in catalyst and FC2H6 is the ethane molar flow rate) was varied between 6.91gcat h/molC2H6 and 20.74gcat h/molC2H6. During the heating up of the fixed-bed reactor, helium was the only gas fed through the reactor tube. Once the reaction temperature was reached, the reagent and the gas feed with the appropriate composition were introduced into the system. The steady-state data of catalyst performance was determined 6h after the beginning of the reaction because there was usually an induction period for the catalysts in oxidative dehydrogenation of alkanes. The reactor effluent was analyzed by an online gas chromatography (GC) equipped with two columns. A PorapakQ column was used to separate CO2, C2H4 and C2H6, while 5A molecular sieve column was used to separate O2, N2, CH4 and CO. A blank run was conducted by loading the reactor with only SiC under the same operating conditions. No ethane conversion was observed, indicating that the effect of the homogeneous gas phase reaction can be neglected. During our experiment, the carbon balances maintained in the range of 95–98% by the detection of volume flow and composition of the outlet gas. We calculated the product selectivity based on the carbon mass balances. The conversion and selectivity for ODHE process are defined as follows: (1) X C 2 H 6 = ( 1 − 2 f C 2 H 6 2 f C 2 H 6 + 2 f C 2 H 4 + f C O + f C O 2 ) × 100 % (2) S C 2 H 4 = ( 2 f C 2 H 4 2 f C 2 H 4 + f C O + f C O 2 ) × 100 % (3) S C O 2 = ( f C O 2 2 f C 2 H 4 + f C O + f C O 2 ) × 100 % (4) S C O = ( f C O 2 f C 2 H 4 + f C O + f C O 2 ) × 100 % where, X is the ethane conversion, S is the selectivity to a certain product, and f is the molar fraction in the effluent gas. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The specific surface area was calculated based on the multipoint Brunauer–Emmett–Teller method (BET) in the p/p0=0.05–0.3 pressure range. Nitrogen adsorption was carried out at 77K on a Quantachrome Autosorb-6B analyzer. Prior to the measurement, the samples were outgassed in vacuum at 110°C for 2h. Inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry(ICP-OES, Varian Vista RL spectrometer) was applied to analyze the metal content of MoVNbTe oxide catalyst. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of samples were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance equipment with Cu Ka radiation in the 2θ range of 0–90°. Phase identification of the catalysts was carried out by comparing the collected spectra with those listed in the JCPDS data base (Joint Committee of Powder Diffraction Standards) and the ICSD data base (Inorganic Crystal Structure Database). The average particle diameter along certain direction can be calculated by Scherrer equation. The temperature programmed reduction by hydrogen (TPR–H2) experiment was carried out using a TP5080 adsorption instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). A 15mg sample was filled in a quartz tube and pretreated with helium, heated up to 100°C at the speed of 10°C/min and held for 30min, then cooled to the room temperature. After that, the carrier gas was switched to 40mL/min 5% H2/Ar before the sample was ramped from 100°C to 800°C at 5°C/min. The morphology of catalysts was characterized using a scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JEOL, JSM-7401F) and a high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM, JEOL, JEM2010), which was also used to detect the dimension distribution of the MoVNbTeOx needlelike particles. 0.01g catalyst powder was dispersed in 5mL ethanol by ultrasonic agitation, and then the suspension was dropped on a carbon-coated copper grid and finally dried in air at 110°C for 2h before the measurement of HR-TEM. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) was acquired using a PHI Quantera SXM system, equipped with Al Ka X-ray source. Survey scans (0–1200eV) and high-resolution Mo (3d), V (2p), Te (3d), Nb (3d) and C (1s) spectra were obtained. The uncertainty of the peak positions was estimated to be 0.2eV for all spectra and the binding energy (BE) scale was regulated by setting the C (1s) transition at 284.6eV. The analysis of the measured high-resolution spectra was performed using XPSPEAK4.1 software. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 General properties of M1 catalyst Chemical and structural details of prepared MoVNbTe oxide catalysts are summarized in Table 1 . It can be seen that the concentration of oxalic acid has obvious impact on the vanadium content, particle diameter and surface area. Oxalic acid itself is usually used as an organic reagents for metal ions leaching or extraction due to its acidity and complexation ability [59,60]. As shown in Table 1, an obvious leaching of vanadium can be observed with the increase of oxalic acid concentration. It is mainly attributed to the strong interaction of oxalic acid and vanadium species in aqueous suspension and the formation of surface dissoluble complexes [61]. The vanadium leaching can be inhibited until the oxalic concentration is lower than 5.0mmol/L. Meanwhile, the oxalic acid treatment shows great influence on the decrease of particle dimension and thus the surface area increases accordingly. Some of M1 catalysts were chosen and compared as two typical catalysts by investigating the effect of oxalic acid treatment on prepared catalysts in details below. 3.2 XRD analysis According to the ICSD data base, M1 phase (ICSD 55097) has characteristic diffraction lines located at 2θ=6.6, 7.7, 8.9, 22.1, and 27.1°, while M2 phase (ICSD 55098) has characteristic diffraction lines located at 2θ=22.1, 28.1 and 36.2°. As shown in Fig. 1 , M2 phase exists in the MoVNbTeOx catalysts after oxalic acid treatment but the relative intensity of characteristic peak of M2 phase (2θ=28.1°) is lower than the catalyst without oxalic acid treatment. In other words, oxalic acid treatment favors the formation of M1 phase but cannot eliminate the generation of M2 phase. It indicates that the oxalic acid does not have the similar purification function of orthorhombic crystal in MoVNbTeOx system as MoVOx system [20]. However, M2 phase in MoVNbTeOx catalysts with or without oxalic acid treatment can be effectively eliminated by H2O2 treatment. The XRD patterns of catalysts after H2O2 treatment are exclusively characterized by reflections that arise from the M1 phase. No peaks were detected related to the presence of any other crystalline phase, especially M2 phase. Moreover, the corresponding peak of [200] crystal direction in the XRD patterns is located at 2θ=7.7°, and the average diameter of particles can be calculated by Scherrer equation. Since the diameter of catalyst M1-0 exceeds 100nm, the exact value of its diameter cannot be estimated by Scherrer equation. The particle diameter of MoVNbTeOx catalysts is extremely decreased from about 100nm to 20nm after the oxalic acid treatment, where the H2O2 treatment has almost no influence on the particle dimension. 3.3 XPS analysis XPS spectra of key element in phase-pure M1 catalysts were measured to investigate the element valence state on the catalyst surface. The binding energy data of reference material was obtained from NIST X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy Database. As shown in Fig. 2 , the binding energy (BE) of Mo3d5/2 (232.9±0.2eV) is close to the value of 232.8eV typically reported for MoO3, and a BE of Nb3d5/2 (207.2±0.2eV) is nearly the same as the value of 207.2eV typically reported for Nb2O5, suggesting a single Mo and Nb valence of respectively +6 and +5 in pure-phase M1 catalysts. However, the BE of Te3d5/2 (576.7±0.2eV) is between the value of 576.2eV for TeO2 and the value of 577.3eV for TeO3. It means that Te4+ and Te6+ species both exist in the catalyst. Moreover, the BE of V2p3/2 (516.9±0.2eV) is between the value of 516.1eV for VO2 and the value of 517.2eV for V2O5, inferring that V element has two valence states of +4 and +5 in the catalyst. Since V5+ is considered as the only active sites for ethane activity [42], the V5+ species abundance on the catalyst surface remains important effect on the catalyst performance in ODHE [62,63]. According to the de-convolution of V2p3/2 and Te3d5/2 peak, the V5+ and Te6+ abundant of phase-pure M1 catalysts can be calculated as shown in Table 2 . There is little difference on the surface metal oxidative state between the M1 catalysts with and without oxalic acid treatment. However, the peak area of V2p3/2 decreased after oxalic acid treatment, implying the loss of vanadium on the catalyst surface. It is consistent with the bulk chemical composition analysis according to ICP-OES method (Table 1). The reduction of total vanadium species on the catalyst surface can lead to the negative effect on the catalyst activity. 3.3.1 SEM and TEM analysis SEM and TEM images of the M1 catalysts are shown in Figs. 3 and 4 , respectively. The morphology of catalysts indicates obvious difference after the oxalic acid treatment. Oxalic acid treatment can decrease the catalyst diameters apparently. The average particle diameter based on the SEM images is consistent with the calculation in Table 1. However, as shown in Fig. 5 , the length of M1 crystal needles change very little through oxalic acid treatment. Millet et al., discovered that precursor materials of phase-pure M1 catalysts themselves owned the long-range order in the [001] direction directly after the hydrothermal synthesis and considered that the length of M1 needles was predetermined by the hydrothermal synthesis [45]. It can help to explain that the M1 catalyst treated with oxalic acid of different concentration would maintain the same particle length due to the same procedure of hydrothermal synthesis. It can also be deduced that the oxalic acid treatment is the main reason to restrain the anisotropic growth of the basal (001) plane of the M1-phasein subsequent calcination in nitrogen. The tendency of catalyst surface area detected by BET method with oxalic acid concentration is also in accordant with the TEM images. The HRTEM images of a representative M1 particle along the [020] zone axis in catalyst M1-0 and M1-40 are shown in Fig. 4, and the corresponding fast Fourier transform pattern is also given as an inset. They reveal an overall crystallinity and M1 structure, being present even for the smallest particles in the samples. The lattice fringes represent the (200) and (001) planes of the orthorhombic M1 structure, implying that the particles grow along the [001] axis. The same lattice fringe spacing determined from images in M1-0 and M1-40 catalyst indicates that the oxalic acid treatment has no extra influence on the crystallinity and crystal structure. Although the oxalic acid treatment can effectively change the dimension of catalyst particles, it has also been observed that the introduction of reducing acid (i.e. oxalic acid) in the synthesis of MoVNbTeOx catalysts can encourage the formation of the M1 phase but the excessive reductant may lead to the agglomeration of Te0 on the surface and produce a negative effect on the catalysts by masking the active sites [64]. In the contrast, the introduction of oxidative strong acid (i.e. HNO3) in the preparation of MoVNbTeOx catalysts can effectively eliminate the surface Te0 but it can increase the content of M2 phase in the final catalyst system [65]. Thus, the introduction of oxidative weak acid (i.e. H2O2) after oxalic acid treatment is necessary to prepare suitable catalyst for ODHE reaction which can clean both Te0 on the surface (i.e.) and M2 phase in the bulk [66]. In our present work, the two-step treatment with oxalic acid and hydrogen peroxide has been proved successful in preparation of phase-pure M1 catalyst (i.e. no peak at 2θ=28.1° in XRD pattern and no peak at 577.3eV in XPS Spectra of Te3d). The morphology of M1 catalysts before calcination was detected to investigate the function of oxalic acid during the preparation. As shown in Fig. 5(A), the starting needles of M1 and M2 phases should be usually composed of several thinner needles which are stuck to each other. The severe agglomeration of M1 and M2 starting needles was also observed by Nguyen et al. [28]. Nguyen et al. prevented the agglomeration by adding colloidal silica Ludox AS40 in the precursor solution to form SiO2 in the final MoVNbTeOx crystal. As a comparison, in Fig. 5(B) we can see that the treatment with oxalic acid can helps to separate these thinner needles from each other effectively without addition of any other phase. Finally, the good separation of the starting needles of MoVNbTeOx restrains the epitaxial growth and leads to the formation of M1 particles with low aspect ratio and high specific area 3.3.2 TPR-H2 analysis According to the TPR-H2 profiles of the M1 catalysts presented in Fig. 6 , one broad peak in the range of 400–700°C is observed for each catalyst, due to the reduction of Mo6+, V5+ and Te6+ species [67]. It is known that Mo6+ and V5+ are reduced more easily in mixed metal oxide solid solution than in pure MoO3 and V2O5 [68]. Although it is difficult to distinguish the corresponding peak for each cation in the mixed metal oxide due to the complex reduction reaction, the broad peak can be resolved to three peaks with the same Lorentzian-Gaussian of 20% by de-convolution. Each peak is assigned to the lattice oxygen with different activity due to the reduction temperature (i.e. OI, OII and OIII). OI exhibits the greatest reducibility whereas OIII is the most difficult to reduce. The reduction temperature of OI is closest to the actual temperature of ODHE reaction and we can deduce that OI represents the part of lattice oxygen functioning in the ODHE reaction. As illustrated in Table 3 , although the OII and OIII peaks of M1-40 catalyst shift to higher temperature than M1-0 catalyst, the peak area fraction of OI in M1-40 catalyst is obviously larger than M1-0 catalyst. M1-1.0 catalyst has the lowest value of OI peak and its peak area distribution is similar to that of M1-0 catalyst. The characterization results above demonstrated that the oxalic acid treatment can realize the controllable preparation of phase-pure M1 with diameter from 20 to 100nm. However, the purity of M1 phase, valence of active component and crystal structure do not substantially change with varying oxalic acid concentration. The loss of vanadium can also be effectively inhibited with appropriate oxalic acid concentration (<5.0mmol/L). 3.4 Catalyst performance in ODHE reaction As demonstrated above, we successfully prepared a number of phase-pure M1 catalysts with different particle dimension. Accordingly, we can evaluate the catalyst structure sensitivity in ODHE reaction by using these catalysts. Figs. 7 and 8 show the catalytic performance of the prepared phase-pure M1 catalysts in the ODHE process. The catalytic activity and selectivity present a strong relevance with the oxalic acid concentration, i.e. particle dimension. This implies the existence of structure sensitivity of phase-pure M1 catalyst in ODHE reaction. As shown in Fig. 7, both the ethane conversion and oxygen conversion increase initially with the oxalic acid concentration, presenting a maximum for an oxalic acid concentration of 1.0mmol/L. However, the catalytic activity obviously decreases for the catalysts prepared from treatment with oxalic acid concentration higher than 1.0mmol/L. Catalyst M1-1.0 gives the best performance, i.e., ethane conversion of 73% and catalyst productivity of 0.77kgC2H4/kg cat/h at 400°C among all the phase-pure M1 catalysts. Since V5+ is identified as the only active site of M1 phase in ODHE reaction [42–45], it can be concluded that the catalyst activity depends on the effective V5+ surface distribution, a combined factor of vanadium content, vanadium valence and surface area. Oxalic acid treatment can augment the catalyst surface area with little impact on the vanadium valence but at the cost of vanadium leaching. The increase of surface area benefits the conversion of ethane but the vanadium leaching can play the opposite role in ODHE reaction. The conflicting influence of surface area and vanadium content on the catalyst activity leads to the optimal catalyst performance with a moderate oxalic acid concentration of 1.0mmol/L and the similarity in conversion of the untreated catalyst and the treated M1-5.0 which possess different surface areas and different V concentration. It has been acknowledged that the active sites of the M1 phase are located on the (001) basal faces of the needle morphology, especially the entrance of the heptagonal channel of the structure [50]. Some studies reported that not only the basal plane, but the entire surface of M1 is involved in the activation of alkanes in selective oxidation [55–57]. It is interesting to note that during the process of tuning the particle size of M1 catalyst by our method, we can maintain the V5+abundance on the catalyst surface by a moderate oxalic acid concentration. The augment of surface area is mainly contributed by the lateral faces of M1 needles. Accordingly, the increase of the catalytic activity from 61% to 73% (catalyst M1-0, M1-0.5 and M1-1.0) is consistent with the latter viewpoint that the active sites of ODHE exist all over the surface of M1 needles. Since the catalysis is mainly performed on the catalyst surface, we calculate the specific surface activity of M1 catalyst for further investigating the structure sensitivity in catalyst activity. The specific area activity of M1-0 is 0.039gC2H4/m2 cat/h. Although the M1-0.5 and M1-1.0 catalyst possess the similar V content as the M1-0 catalyst, the specific area activity of these catalysts with oxalic acid treatment (∼0.018gC2H4/m2 cat/h) is at least 50% lower than the catalyst without oxalic acid treatment. It implies that V content is not the primary factor in the catalyst specific area activity. On the contrary, the good linear correlation is observed between catalyst specific area activity and aspect ratio as shown in Fig. 9 . It can be deduced that the active sites of the M1 phase located on the (001) basal faces is more active than that located on the lateral faces. By decreasing the diameter of M1 needles, the oxalic acid treatment can only expose more lateral faces with the decrease of the proportion of basal faces in the surface area and thus lead to the lower specific area activity in M1 catalyst. The structure sensitivity exists in the catalyst activity and the difference of specific area activity mainly results from the structure sensitivity. Consequently, the best catalytic performance of M1-1.0 is a combination of the positive influence of increasing the specific area and the negative influence of decreasing the specific area activity in catalyst activity. As evidenced in Fig. 10 , the increase of oxalic acid concentration results in an obvious decrease in the catalytic ethylene selectivity. It has meant that the morphology change caused by oxalic acid treatment may be beneficial to deep oxidation to form CO2 and CO. Lattice oxygen serves as an important factor of catalyst selectivity in the selective oxidation of alkanes [69]. Dai et al., proposed that the adsorbed oxygen species on a perovskite-type catalyst surface were prone to induce ethane complete oxidation, while lattice oxygen species were active for ethane selective oxidation [70,71]. Heracleous et al. suggested that oxygen in the NiNbOx catalyst lattice produced two types of active sites, one responsible for the ethylene formation and ethylene total oxidation, and the other involved in the ethane total oxidation [72,73]. Ishikawa et al. considered that the ethane could go through the heptagonal channel micropores located at the (001) plane of orthorhombic Mo3VOx catalyst and be activated and converted to ethylene by oxidative dehydrogenation with lattice oxygen of the heptagonal channel [74]. Therefore, we can assume that there also exist two different active oxygen species respectively on the lateral faces and basal faces of phase-pure M1 catalyst. The active oxygen species on the lateral faces consist of adsorbed oxygen and lattice oxygen, participating in both ODHE to form ethylene and deep oxidation to form carbon oxides. But the active oxygen species on the basal faces correspond to the lattice oxygen in the heptagonal channel, beneficial only the selective oxidation from ethane to ethylene. With the assumption of the phase-pure M1 particle as a cylindrical geometry, the variation of the area ratio of basal faces to lateral faces with the oxalic acid concentration is illustrated in Fig. 10. The same tendency of catalyst ethylene selectivity and morphology with the oxalic acid concentration verifies the assumption proposed above and also implies that phase-pure M1 catalyst with lower aspect ratio will provide better ethylene selectivity in ODHE process. As shown in Fig. 8, the non-treated catalyst shows the highest selectivity due to its lowest aspect ratio among all the catalysts. The particle dimensions also have obvious influence on the reducibility of lattice oxygen in M1 catalyst (Table 3). It has been reported that weakly bonded reactive lattice oxygen is responsible for the over-oxidation of ethane and ethylene in ODHE reaction [75], which can probably be ascribed to OI in this work. As shown in Table 3, higher OI fraction appears in the catalyst with higher aspect ratio, which implies lower ethylene selectivity in ODHE (catalyst M1-0, M1-1.0 and M1-40). It can also explain the structure sensitivity of ODHE selectivity of phase-pure M1 catalyst and coincide with the analysis above. 4 Conclusion An effective oxalic acid treatment method was proposed to modulate the morphology of phase-pure M1 ODHE catalysts. This method decreased the dimension of precursor particles due to the separation of starting needles of MoVNbTe oxides by oxalic acid treatment and restrained the anisotropic growth of the basal (001) plane of the M1 and M2 phase in subsequent calcination in nitrogen, remarkably decreasing the diameter of M1 particles from 100nm to 20nm. However, the purity of M1 phase and valence of active component did not substantially change with varying oxalic acid concentration and the loss of vanadium could also be effectively inhibited with moderate oxalic acid concentration. The high surface area favored the formation of ethylene and phase-pure M1 catalyst treated with 1.0mmol/L oxalic acid solution showed the best catalyst performance of 73% ethane conversion, 85% ethylene selectivity and 0.77kgC2H4/kgcat/h catalyst productivity at 400°C. The series of phase-pure M1 catalysts with different dimensions were utilized to study the structure sensitivity of M1 phase in the ODHE reaction. Active sites located both on the lateral faces and the basal plane of the M1 needles. However, the structure sensitivity of M1 phase both existed in the catalyst activity and selectivity. It was demonstrated that the active sites of the M1 phase located on the (001) basal faces was more active in ODHE reaction than that located on the lateral faces. The oxalic acid treatment increased the catalyst surface area at the cost of losing the catalyst specific activity. The active oxygen species located on the lateral faces of M1 phase were deduced to have the activity of both selective oxidation and deep oxidation while the ones located on the basal faces participated in only ODHE from ethane to ethylene. The phase-pure M1 catalyst with higher surface area and lower aspect ratio was suggested to provide better catalytic performance in ODHE process. coredata.dc:description: This work presented a comprehensive study on structure sensitivity of phase-pure M1 catalyst in oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane (ODHE). We proposed an effective method to modulate the morphology of phase-pure M1 catalysts by oxalic acid treatment. The proposed approach significantly promoted the catalyst surface area by restraining the anisotropic growth of the basal (001) plane of the M1-phase in calcination and decreased the diameter of M1 needles. Experimental results showed that phase-pure M1 catalyst treated with 1.0mmol/L oxalic acid solution exhibited remarkably promoted catalyst performance of 73% ethane conversion, 85% ethylene selectivity and 0.77k C2H4/kgcat/h catalyst productivity at 400°C. The serial catalyst tests also demonstrated the structure sensitivity of M1 phase in the ODHE reaction. Active sites were located on the lateral faces as well as the basal plane of the M1 needles, but different effects on the catalyst selectivity were observed. The phase-pure M1 catalyst with a lower aspect ratio was suggested to provide better ethylene selectivity in ODHE process.
